Bank of England Cuts Base Rate to 4.25% Amid Global Trade Concerns
The Bank of England reduced its base interest rate from 4.5% to 4.25%, aiming to support the UK economy.

On May 8, 2025, the Bank of England reduced its base interest rate from 4.5% to 4.25%. This aims to cushion the UK economy from global trade uncertainties. Homeowners with variable or tracker mortgages may benefit.

Economic Forecast: Bank of England Projects Modest Growth Post Rate Cut
The BoE forecasts 1% GDP growth for 2025 with cautious optimism.
The Bank of England forecasts a 1% GDP growth for 2025, factoring in the 4.25% base rate and global trade factors. Growth remains cautious amid inflation control measures.

HMRC Adjusts Interest Rates Following Bank of England's Decision
HMRC updates interest rates for late payments after the Bank's base rate change.
HMRC has announced updated interest rates for late payments and repayments. These changes follow the Bank of England's new 4.25% base rate and will take effect in mid-May.

Interest Rate Cut: What It Means for Your Savings and Investments
Borrowers benefit from lower rates, but savers may see reduced returns.
While borrowers may benefit from the lower interest rate, savers could see reduced returns. Review your savings and investment plans to adapt to the rate shift.

Mortgage Lenders Respond to Interest Rate Cut with Competitive Deals
Lenders are now offering improved fixed-rate mortgage deals following the rate cut.
Following the Bank of England's rate cut to 4.25%, UK lenders are offering better fixed-rate deals. Borrowers should consider total costs including fees before switching.

UK and US Announce Trade Deal Amid Interest Rate Adjustments
A new trade agreement is signed as interest rates are adjusted, boosting market confidence.
The UK and US signed a new trade agreement shortly after the Bank of England’s rate cut. The deal is expected to boost market confidence and support economic growth.
